channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: ISIS Forays Send Waves of Refugees Into Turkey
item.description: The refugee crisis near the Syrian border town of Ayn al-Arab could be one of the greatest refugee flows since the civil war in Syria began, said a United Nations official.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: A Turkish soldier at the border in Suruc, Turkey, threw a pack of water Sunday to Syrian refugees fleeing Islamic State militants.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Bottom-Up Climate Fix
item.description: International treaties haven’t worked. Enabling local and corporate leaders could.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: By DANIEL C. ESTY

item.title: Obama to Lead U.N. Effort to Halt Movement of Terror Recruits
item.description: An unusual meeting of the United Nations Security Council is poised to adopt a resolution that would compel all countries to adopt laws to prosecute those who travel abroad to join terrorist organizations and those who help them.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Sex Geckos' Sacrifice
item.description: The demise of these lizards should make us question the ethics of animal research in space.
item.dc:creator: By AMY NELSON

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Beijing's Rising Smear Power
item.description: The online slander of dissidents is seen as an attempt to manipulate opinion on a global scale.
item.dc:creator: By MURONG XUECUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Glen Peters on China and Climate Change
item.description: A scientist with the Global Carbon Project argues that China holds the key to promoting renewable energy and limiting global warming.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Smoke rising from chimneys and cooling towers of a thermal power plant in Liaoning Province, China.

item.title: Yemen’s Prime Minister Resigns Amid Chaos and Another Cease-Fire
item.description: Mohammed Salem Basindwa submitted his resignation to the Yemeni president as fighters from a Shiite rebel group seized official buildings in an assault on the capital that rocked the transitional government.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Governing Party Claims Victory in Provincial Election
item.description: In the election in Uva Province, which was seen as a test of President Mahinda Rajapaksa’s re-election prospects, the governing party secured a majority of seats, but its margin of victory was smaller than in 2009.
item.dc:creator: By DHARISHA BASTIANS and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: China and Iran to Conduct Joint Naval Exercises in the Persian Gulf
item.description: Two Chinese warships have docked at Iran’s principal naval port for the first time in history, Iranian admirals said, as they prepared for exercises focusing on rescues and anti-piracy operations.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Global Rise Reported in 2013 Greenhouse Gas Emissions
item.description: The report on the emissions growth, 2.3 percent last year, showed that the world remains far off track in efforts to control global warming and came on the eve of a United Nations summit meeting on tackling climate change.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:description: The view from a coal-fired power plant in China's Hunan Province in June. China emits 10 billion tons of carbon dioxide a year from fossil fuel burning and cement manufacture.

item.title: International Education: Campus Police Acquire Military Weapons
item.description: At least 124 colleges have acquired military equipment through a federal program that transfers military surplus to law-enforcement agencies across the country.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BAUMAN | THE CHRONICLE OF HIGHER EDUCATION
item.media:credit: Julia Schmalz/The Chronicle of Higher Education.
item.media:description: Equipment at the University of Maryland at College Park leased through the Department of Defense program. The university leases three vehicles and 50 M-16 rifles.

item.title: Ashraf Ghani Is Named President of Afghanistan by Elections Panel
item.description: The election commission on Sunday pronounced Mr. Ghani the winner of the country’s presidential election after he and Abdullah Abdullah signed a power-sharing agreement.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Ashraf Ghani, right, was declared president of Afghanistan after he and Abdullah Abdullah, left, signed a power-sharing agreement in Kabul on Sunday. Mr. Abdullah will effectively become a prime minister.

item.title: Chinese Tourists Find a Movable Feast Best Left Behind
item.description: The French capital is the No. 1 destination in Europe for Chinese tourists, but many have unrealistic expectations of the city.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:credit: Marlene Awaad for The New York Times
item.media:description: On the Pont de l'Archevêché in Paris this month. The French capital is the No. 1 destination in Europe for China’s expanding middle class and legion of millionaires.

item.title: U.S. Criticizes Efforts to Intimidate Times Reporter in Turkey
item.description: The correspondent has been attacked online and denounced as a traitor after publication of an article about Islamic State recruiting in Turkey.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Paris Falls Out of Love With the Padlocks on Its Bridges
item.description: Thick glass, with nothing to hitch a lock to, has begun replacing the panels where thousands have symbolized everlasting devotion by fastening hardware.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:credit: Marlene Awaad for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vendors continue to sell padlocks on the Pont des Arts bridge in Paris, France. The city plans to remove "love locks" and replace them with glazed panels.

item.title: Turkey Obtains Release of Hostages Held in Iraq
item.description: Forty-nine hostages held by Islamic State militants were returned to Turkey on Saturday after what Turkey said was a covert operation led by its intelligence agency.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD, SEBNEM ARSU and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu of Turkey, center, in suit, welcomed freed hostages Saturday as they arrived at Esenboga Airport in Ankara on Saturday.

item.title: U.N. Reports Yemen Deal With Rebels
item.description: Fighting between the transitional government and Shiite rebels continued Saturday in the streets of the capital, Sana
item.dc:creator: By SHUAIB ALMOSAWA
item.media:description: Anti-government rebels, known as Houthis, guarded a street near the Sana airport on Saturday. Airlines have stopped flights there as clashes between the rebels and the government continued.

item.title: Provincial Vote Is Seen as a Test for Sri Lanka’s President
item.description: The candidates for chief minister of Uva Province are seen as proxies for President Mahinda Rajapaksa’s coming battle for re-election.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS and DHARISHA BASTIANS

item.title: U.S. Suspects More Direct Threats Beyond ISIS
item.description: A Syrian group led by a former member of Osama bin Laden’s inner circle is seen as more dangerous than the Islamic State for its potential to launch terror attacks.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI, MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Afghan Presidential Rivals Finally Agree on Power-Sharing Deal
item.description: In negotiations over the disputed presidential election, Abdullah Abdullah, who is widely expected to lose, has insisted that the count not be made public.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: The Afghan presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah in Kabul this month.

item.title: Push for New Pact on Climate Change Is Plagued by Old Divide of Wealth
item.description: At a United Nations gathering on Tuesday, leaders will face a divide between the rich countries responsible for extensive carbon emissions and the poor countries that stand to suffer most as a result.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS and CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: President Christopher J. Loeak of the Marshall Islands outside his home after tidal flooding.

item.title: Venezuela Moves Jailed Former Police Official to House Arrest
item.description: The opposition has long demanded the release of the official, Iván Simonovis, who was jailed in connection with the killing of protesters in 2002, but the Supreme Court said that he would be returned to jail once his health improved.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Opinion: Climate Realities
item.description: The world is now on track to more than double current greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere by the end of the century.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT N. STAVINS

item.title: Opinion: Farewell, Rob Ford
item.description: Why Toronto will secretly miss its mayor.
item.dc:creator: By BRUCE MCCALL

item.title: In Ruins of Ukrainian Town, Residents Crave Food, Water and Peace
item.description: As residents began repairing the damage in Luhansk and taking stock of the calamity around them, many said they no longer cared about the politics that caused it all.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pro-Russian rebel walking in the rubble of the Luhansk airport recently after Ukrainian forces were driven out.
